messages.message:
@Jesika Haria @dlluncor Just ran into this in `train_refiner_util` and was wondering if y'all knew if it was intentional:

```
  records, iberr = apply_refiner_fns.refine_extract_ibocr(
      orig_ibocr, [saved_program], '', ibocr, ctx, fn_ctx_reader, clients)
  return records, None
```

We're silently swallowing any refiner error that happens. I'm hesitant to switch that `None` to an `iberr` since I know sometimes our customer depend upon very specific quirks of flow/refiner behavior.... anyone know if suppressing the error is intentional?

not intentional. Looking at the code, when iberr != None is very rare. So if we catch the iberr there, it’s OK.

In reality, we swallow the majority of Refiner running exceptions with try catch blocks inside of refiner_util.py
So `not intentional, but don't fix` seems to be the read on it?
not intentional, you can fix it — i don’t anticipate it will have a worrisome impact, because iberr is None the vast majority of the time, unless your IBOCR is really a borked format
for sure — good to be very explicit :slightly_smiling_face: — you can fix it though i’d say, not a high risk change
@Ted that was a bug -- i should be checking for the error and returning
but that said, it's another reason why raising exceptions is better :slightly_smiling_face:
just fyi that function is only used by refiner 5 (i added it)
it provides a way to run refiner with provenance outside of flow
also I can fix it tomorrow
Oh it's just R5! Cool. I thought it was in the refiner classic pathway so was afraid to change anything
